title: Eye gaze mapping
code: library(BiDimRegression) library(dplyr) library(ggplot2)  ggplot(data= EyegazeData, aes(x= x, y= y, color= target, fill= target)) +   geom_point(data= EyegazeData %>% group_by(target, target_x, target_y) %>% summarise(),              aes(x= target_x, y= target_y), shape= 21, size= 10, fill= 'white') +    geom_point(alpha= 0.5, shape= 21) +    ggtitle('Raw eye gaze')

what: Using lm2 to transform the eye gaze
title: Eye gaze mapping
code: lm2aff <- lm2(target_x + target_y ~ x + y,  EyegazeData, transformation = 'affine') adjusted_gaze <- data.frame(predict(lm2aff)) colnames(adjusted_gaze) <- c('adjX', 'adjY') adjusted_gaze <- cbind(EyegazeData, adjusted_gaze)   ggplot(data= adjusted_gaze, aes(x= adjX, y= adjY, color= target, fill= target)) +   geom_point(data= adjusted_gaze %>% group_by(target, target_x, target_y) %>% summarise(),              aes(x= target_x, y= target_y), shape= 21, size= 10, fill= 'white') +    geom_point(alpha= 0.5, shape= 21) +    xlab('x')+   ylab('y')+   ggtitle('Adjusted eye gaze') #> `summarise()` has grouped output by 'target', 'target_x'. You can override using the `.groups` argument.

text: Package calculate bidimensional regression two 2D configurations following approach Tobler (1965). package described detail : Carbon, C. C. (2013). BiDimRegression: Bidimensional Regression Modeling Using R. Journal Statistical Software, Code Snippets, 52(1), 1-11, doi: 10.18637/jss.v052.c01.

title: Calculates the Bidimensional Regression Between Two 2D Configurations
Calculates the Bidimensional Regression Between Two 2D Configurations
text: Using legacy BiDimRegression function: Using lm2 S3-class:
code: print(BiDimRegression(NakayaData)) lm2euc <- lm2(depV1 + depV2 ~ indepV1 + indepV2, NakayaData, 'euclidean') lm2aff <- lm2(depV1 + depV2 ~ indepV1 + indepV2, NakayaData, 'affine') lm2prj <- lm2(depV1 + depV2 ~ indepV1 + indepV2, NakayaData, 'projective') anova(lm2euc, lm2aff, lm2prj predict(lm2euc) summary(lm2euc)

title: Calculates the Bidimensional Regression Between Two 2D Configurations

Tobler, now Professor Emeritus Department Geography, University California, Santa Barbara, providing original publications helpful correspondence Dan Montello calling author’s attention Tobler’s work many years ago. like thank Alinda Friedman, Gregory Francis, Jan de Leeuw, Achim Zeileis, two anonymous reviewers Arne Terkowski valuable comments earlier version paper, Andrea Lyman Vera M. Hesslinger proofreading manuscript. Last least, indepted Tomoki Nakaya, developed original inference statistics overall models referring parameters helped reanalyzing statistics well ensuring reliability used methods. Thank !

title: Calculates the Bidimensional Regression Between Two 2D Configurations

Annals Association American Geographers, 56(2), 351-360. Tobler, W. R. (1994). Bidimensional regression. Geographical Analysis, 26(3), 187-212. Friedman, ., & Kohler, B. (2003). Bidimensional regression: Assessing configural similarity accuracy cognitive maps two-dimensional data sets. Psychological Methods, 8(4), 468-491. Nakaya, T. (1997). Statistical inferences bidimensional regression models. Geographical Analysis, 29(2), 169-186. Waterman, S., & Gordon, D. (1984). quantitative-comparative approach analysis distortion mental maps. Professional Geographer, 36(3), 326-337.

title: Anova for lm2 objects — anova.lm2
code: lm2euc <- lm2(depV1+depV2~indepV1+indepV2, NakayaData, transformation = 'Euclidean') lm2aff <- lm2(depV1+depV2~indepV1+indepV2, NakayaData, transformation = 'Affine') anova(lm2euc, lm2aff) #> Bidimensional regression: #>                          dAIC df1 df2      F   p.value     #> euclidean vs. affine -13.2902   2  32 9.2189 0.0006891 *** #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1

what: Calculates the bidimensional regression between two 2D configurations — BiDimRegression
title: Calculates the bidimensional regression between two 2D configurations — BiDimRegression
text: Calculates bidimensional regression two 2D configurations using Euclidean Affine transformations following approach Tobler (1965). function assumes strict data format returns coefficients statistics single structure. functionality now re-implemented R-friendly style, see lm2 function.

title: Calculates the bidimensional regression between two 2D configurations — BiDimRegression
Calculates the bidimensional regression between two 2D configurations — BiDimRegression
text: coord table must contain two columns dependent variables (named depV1 depV2) two columns independent variables (named indepV1 indepV2).

title: Calculates the bidimensional regression between two 2D configurations — BiDimRegression
text: S3 class BiDimRegression containing essential measures bidimensional regression euclidean.r, affine.r - regression coefficient, defined analogously Pearson's r. euclidean.rsqr, affine.rsqr - squared regression coefficient. euclidean.diABSqr, affine.diABSqr - squared distortion index dependent variables; following Waterman Gordon's (1984) extension bidimensional regression, provides measure comparison distortions, range values 0 1 following Friedman Kohler (2003). euclidean.dMaxABSqr, affine.dMaxABSqr - maximal squared distortion index dependent variables. euclidean.diXYSqr, affine.diXYSqr - distortion index independent variables. euclidean.dMaxXYSqr, affine.dMaxXYSqr - maximal squared distortion index independent variables. euclidean.scaleFactorX, affine.scaleFactorX - scaling factor first dimension (1.0 means scaling; values 1.0 indicate contraction, values 1.0 indicate expansion). euclidean.scaleFactorY, affine.scaleFactorY - scaling factor second dimension. euclidean.angleDEG, affine.angleDEG - rotation angle degrees. euclidean.shear, affine.shear - shearing transformed configuration, always zero Euclidean transformation. euclidean.ttestDF, affine.ttestDF - degrees freedom (DF) t-tests regarding model parameters (alphas betas). euclidean.alpha1.*, euclidean.alpha2.*, affine.alpha1.*, affine.alpha2.* - intercept vectors, information includes .coeff coefficient, .SE standard error, tValue t-statistics, pValue significance. euclidean.beta1.*, euclidean.beta2.*, affine.beta1.*, affine.beta2.*, affine.beta3.*, affine.beta4.* - slope vectors, information includes .coeff coefficient, .SE standard error, tValue t-statistics, pValue significance. euclidean.fValue, affine.fValue -  F-statistics, following advice Nakaya (1997). euclidean.df1, affine.df1 -  degrees freedom nominator used F-statistics propagated Nakaya (1997); df1 = p-2, p number elements  needed calculate referring model: p=4 Euclidean p=6 affine geometry Nakaya, 1997, Table 1. euclidean.df2, affine.df2 -  degrees freedom denominator used F-statistics propagated Nakaya (1997); df2 = 2n-p, p number elements needed calculate referring model (see df1) n number coordinate pairs. euclidean.pValue, affine.pValue -  significance level based preceding F-statistics. euclidean.dAICso, affine.dAICso -  AIC difference regarding bidimensional regression model bidimensional null model (S0) according Nakaya (1997), formula 56. eucVSaff.* - statistical comparison Euclidean Affine models, include .fValue F-statistics, .df1 .df2 degrees freedom, .pValue significance level, .dAIC AIC difference two models.

Fitting Bidimensional Regression Models — lm2
text: lm2 used fit bidimensional linear regression models using Euclidean Affine transformations following approach Tobler (1965).

title: Fitting Bidimensional Regression Models — lm2
Fitting Bidimensional Regression Models — lm2
text: formula symbolic description model fitted format + B ~ C + D, B dependent C D independent variables data data frame containing variables model. transformation transformation used, either 'euclidean', 'affine', 'projective'.

title: Fitting Bidimensional Regression Models — lm2
text: lm2 returns object class "lm2". object class "lm" list containing least following components: transformation string transformation type (euclidean, affine, projective) npredictors number predictors used model: 4 euclidean, 6 affine, 8 projective. df_model, df_residual degrees freedom model residuals transformation_matrix 3x3 transformation matrix coeff transformation coefficients, denoting intercept terms. transformed_coeff scale, angle, sheer coefficients, depends transformation. fitted_values data frame containing fitted values original data set residuals data frame containing residuals  original fit r.squared, adj.r.squared R-squared adjusted R-squared. F, p.value F-statistics corresponding p-value, given df_model df_residual degrees freedom. dAIC Akaike Information Criterion (AIC) difference regression model null model. negative values indicates regression model better. See Nakaya (1997). distortion_index Distortion index following Waterman Gordon (1984), adjusted Friedman Kohler (2003) lm underlying linear model Euclidean affine transformations. formula formula, describing input output columns data data used fit model Call function call information, incorporates formula, transformation, data.

title: Fitting Bidimensional Regression Models — lm2
